extendedIngredients.name: bird's eye chiles
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 fresh red bird's-eye chiles, halved lengthwise, seeded, and thinly sliced lengthwise

extendedIngredients.name: cucumber
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 large cucumber, halved lengthwise and thinly sliced on the diagonal (do not peel)

extendedIngredients.name: fish sauce
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 tablespoons Vietnamese fish sauce, preferably Phu Quoc brand

extendedIngredients.name: fresh basil
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 bunch fresh basil, leaves only, large leaves torn

extendedIngredients.name: fresh mint
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 cup fresh mint, leaves only, large leaves torn

extendedIngredients.name: kaffir lime leaves
extendedIngredients.originalString: 4 fresh kaffir lime leaves, center veins removed, cut into julienne

extendedIngredients.name: lemon juice
extendedIngredients.originalString: 3 tablespoons freshly squeezed lime or lemon juice

extendedIngredients.name: red onion
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 red onion, peeled, halved crosswise, and cut into thin rings

extendedIngredients.name: roast beef
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 pound rare roast beef, cut across the grain into paper-thin slices, then into thin strips

extendedIngredients.name: sesame oil
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 tablespoon best quality sesame oil (such as Leblanc)

extendedIngredients.name: tamari
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 teaspoons tamari or other Japanese soy sauce

recipes.title: Cook the Book: Thai Beef Salad

winePairing.pairingText: Thai Beef Salad on the menu? Try pairing with Chardonnay, Gruener Veltliner, and Sauvignon Blanc. Sauvignon Blanc and Gruner Veltliner both have herby notes that complement salads with enough acid to match tart vinaigrettes, while a Chardonnay can be a good pick for creamy salad dressings. You could try Chehalem INOX Chardonnay. Reviewers quite like it with a 4.1 out of 5 star rating and a price of about 13 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Chehalem INOX Chardonnay
productMatches.description: INOX® takes its name from the abbreviation of the French word for stainless steel, inoxydable. The wine was created differently from most Chardonnay you've had. We think we've succeeded in expressing the crisp, steely, and fruit-rich side that we love about some Old-World Chardonnays. What makes this possible is the use of exclusively Dijon clones, exceptionally well suited to Oregon's cool climate and exhibiting a richness that does not depend on oak. INOX screams of the hallmarks of a cool climate-brightness, pinpoint fruit, and explosive aromas and flavors. We intend INOX for a full range of use, from hot weather chilling to elegant dinner complements.Quintessential INOX, with lovely white aromas of gardenia and other flowers, peach, apricot, pear, pineapple, and green apple candy showing on the nose and palate; it shows a great balance with relatively low alcohol for the year and bright acid; the length is lovely and the weight rich, with a supple, silky texture; flavors linger, with cherry and peach accents. Very pleased.

recipes.instructions: Procedures                                                                              1                                                                            In the small jar, whisk together the citrus juice, fish sauce, sesame oil, tamari, ginger, and garlic. Cover and shake to blend. Taste for seasoning.                                                                                                                            2                                                                            Layer the beef in a glass or ceramic dish. Pour half the dressing over the beef. Cover and refrigerate for 2 hours, turning the meat from time to time, to infuse the meat with the dressing.                                                                                                                            3                                                                            At serving time, combine the tomatoes, cucumber, onion, and chiles in a large, shallow bowl. Toss with the remaining dressing. Add the beef and toss to coat. Serve, garnished with the herbs, peanuts, and kaffir lime leaves.

steps.step: In the small jar, whisk together the citrus juice, fish sauce, sesame oil, tamari, ginger, and garlic. Cover and shake to blend. Taste for seasoning.
Layer the beef in a glass or ceramic dish.
Pour half the dressing over the beef. Cover and refrigerate for 2 hours, turning the meat from time to time, to infuse the meat with the dressing.
At serving time, combine the tomatoes, cucumber, onion, and chiles in a large, shallow bowl. Toss with the remaining dressing.
Add the beef and toss to coat.
Serve, garnished with the herbs, peanuts, and kaffir lime leaves.
